newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU, US, Japan agree drugs-approval streamlining.
newsitem.headline: EU, US, Japan agree drugs-approval streamlining.

text.p: The European Union, Japan and the United States have agreed to develop a common document to streamline regulatory procedures for pharmaceutical products in the three regions, participants in the talks said on Wednesday.

The agreement, which aims to cut down on costly duplication, came during the fourth International Conference on Harmonisation (ICH), which unites EU, Japanese and U.S. regulators and industry officials.
"This is going to be the main project over the next two years," Patrick Deboyser, head of pharmaceuticals at the European Commission, told a news conference.
The parties agreed that companies seeking approval for a new drug should be able to provide technical information on a common document that could be submitted to all three regulatory authorities.

Alexander Giaquinto of the Schering-Plough Research Institute in the United States said a recent survey showed that European and U.S. companies spent an average of three months on adapting their drug-approval applications to the other market.
"That's three months of lost time," he said.
The participants decided against working toward a completely common dossier, however, because of legal and administrative differences between the three regions, he said.
A first meeting of experts on the "common technical document" has been scheduled for next January, Giaquinto said.

The ICH was set up in 1990 to harmonise procedures for developing and registering new medicines. The body has completed a first phase by developing about 40 guidelines on the safety, efficacy and quality of drugs, tests, studies and clinical trials. -- Suzanne Perry, Brussels Newsroom 32 2 287 6800
